issues.description: The problem statement (UML and the task text) refers to a public method printFarmSong():void, but both the provided template and the reference solution use the method name singFarmSong() (public void singFarmSong()). The template's Main also calls farm.singFarmSong(). This name/signature mismatch between the specification and the code artifacts will confuse students about which method to implement and which name the tests will expect.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the method name consistent across all artifacts. Either (A) change the problem statement (UML and task text) to refer to singFarmSong() everywhere, or (B) rename the template and solution methods from singFarmSong() to printFarmSong(). Prefer the first option (update the problem statement to singFarmSong()) so it matches the provided template and reference solution and avoids forcing changes to code scaffolding and tests.

issues.description: The problem statement (UML and tasks) refers to a Farm method named printFarmSong(), but both the template and the reference solution implement and reference a method named singFarmSong() (and Main.java calls singFarmSong()). This naming mismatch means a student following the problem text will look for printFarmSong() in the starter code to complete the task but will only find singFarmSong(), causing unnecessary confusion about which method to implement or modify.
issues.suggested_fix:
Make the method name consistent across artifacts. Either:
- Rename the method in template and solution from singFarmSong() to printFarmSong(), and update all references (including Main.java and the UML) accordingly; OR
- Update the problem statement and UML to refer to singFarmSong() instead of printFarmSong().
Choose one name and apply it everywhere so students can unambiguously map the task to the provided code.
